chats.Vlad Dolgopolov: No - histogram contains 100% of your data. The area of the histogram bars is 100%.
@Srinivasulu: They can be, to a degree - a well-selected bin size is important.
We do not share the slidedeck, but you can rely on the recording.

chats.Srinivasulu Malagari: Prof .  is there a recommended bin size as a thumb rule ?

chats.Vlad Dolgopolov: When you are plotting datapoints that show relationship between two variables, and try to figure out trends in this relationship.

chats.Abbas Khan: One way to simply the Histogram vs. Bar Graph understanding is to refer to the Module 1 topic of Quantitative data vs. Qualitative data. Qualitative data can be Nominative and Ordinal. Histograms can only be used for Quantitative data. Bar Graphs are used for Qualitative data.

chats.Jas Singh: Way to detect cooked books by looking at the data on the occurrences of digits in the data: https://abcnews.go.com/Technology/WhosCounting/story?id=98043&page=1

chats.Pawan Upadhyay: Prof Vlad.. What does it mean by characteristics of a histogram? does it mean Range and mode etc.?

chats.Velineni Rao: Prof Dutta - your passion for data integrity and facts (and question the misleading facts) is very inspiring

chats.Vlad Dolgopolov: @Pawan: Is this about Question 6? I think it's about characteristics of the two cities, not the characteristics of the histogram.

chats.Abbas Khan: Also, the entirety of data in the histogram vs. bar graphs is not the correct way to understand it. Both can be complete data sets. Its the type of data itself (quantitative vs. Qualitative) that dictates which type of statistical graphing to use....
